units.name: kilogram
units.description:
**Kilogram â€“ symbol kg**  
The kilogram is the SI base unit of mass and the only one demoted from a physical artefact to a pure constant of nature. Since 20â€¯Mayâ€¯2019 (World Metrology Day) the kilogram has been defined by fixing the numerical value of Planckâ€™s constant *h* to exactly 6.626â€¯070â€¯15â€¯Ã—â€¯10â€‘34â€¯JÂ·s. In practice a sophisticated electromechanical **Kibble balance** equates mechanical power to electrical power traceable to quantum Hall and Josephson effects, realising the kilogram anywhere electricity and an atomic clock are available.

**Evolution in a nutshell**  
â€¢ 1795: defined as the mass of 1â€¯dmÂ³ of water at the melting point of ice  
â€¢ 1889â€“2019: international prototype kilogram (IPK) â€“ a platinumâ€‘iridium cylinder kept near Paris  
â€¢ 2019â€“present: constantâ€‘ofâ€‘nature definition removing dependency on any material object

**Everyday anchors & conversions**  
â€¢ 1â€¯kg â‰ˆ 2.204â€¯622â€¯621â€¯85 pounds (lb)  
â€¢ 500â€¯g = 0.5â€¯kg (standard butter block)  
â€¢ 1â€¯000â€¯kg = 1â€¯tonne (t, metric ton)  
The kilogram powers commerce (grocery scales), health (bodyâ€‘mass index), engineering (load calculations), and international trade documentation.
